importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The GPEI is expected to face a 30% budget reduction starting in 2026, directly impacting funding for polio eradication activities.
A $1.7 billion funding gap is projected through 2029, threatening long-term eradication efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2026 to 2029 marks the critical phase of the funding shortfall, during which reduced resources could derail polio eradication progress.

keyTakeAways: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) faces a $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029 due to reduced foreign aid, especially from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom.
The WHO’s director of polio eradication, Jamal Ahmed, warns that a 30% budget reduction in 2026 will mean certain activities—like vaccination campaigns—will not happen.
The GPEI will shift focus to high-risk areas such as Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases have been reported, and will adopt fractional dosing to stretch vaccine supplies.
Vaccine-derived polio cases have increased in 149 countries, including Nigeria, due to the shedding of weakened virus in unvaccinated populations.
Despite ongoing challenges, experts maintain that polio eradication remains feasible and emphasize the importance of continued vaccination and surveillance.
Wild polio cases have declined since 2024, with 36 cases reported in 2025 in Afghanistan and Pakistan, the only countries where the disease remains endemic.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), led by the World Health Organization and including the Gates Foundation, is facing a severe funding shortfall of $1.7 billion through 2029 due to reduced contributions from major donors such as the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom. This shortfall, driven by a projected 30% budget reduction starting in 2026, threatens critical vaccination and surveillance activities. To address the crisis, the GPEI will concentrate efforts on high-risk areas like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases have been reported, and will adopt innovative strategies such as fractional dosing to conserve vaccine supplies. Meanwhile, cases of vaccine-derived polio have increased in 149 countries, including Nigeria, emphasizing the importance of continued vaccination and monitoring. Despite these challenges, experts maintain that polio eradication remains feasible if global partners remain committed.
title: WHO warns $1.7bn funding shortfall threatens polio eradication efforts
